fields.label_text:
The Rise and Fall of Little Voice

Author: Jim Cartwright
Venue: The Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester

Set and Costume Designer
Liz Ascroft

'I concentrated on creating the space from Little Voice's agoraphobic point of view. Everything is laid wide open and exposed. Little Voice's precise journeys around the house are her way of controlling some of her fears and feelings of exposure, she abides compulsively to the rules of the laid out house while others freak her out by walking freely throughout the house.'

Sound Designer
Peter Rice

'Collaborating on this show created a few challenges. Because the house was split and laid out, naturalistic sounds like door knocks, stones thrown against windows and cars approaching needed to come from underneath the stage behind the relevant places in the floor.

The record revolve in the centre gave me a position to localize the recorded soundtrack of the medley that L.V. sings to. Making one revolution over the 5 minute medley meant that Liz and I made sure all the audience experienced the same listening perspective. A normally near impossible thing to achieve with sound in the round.'

Company: The Royal Exchange - February 2002

Director: Sarah Frankom
Set and Costume Designer: Liz Ascroft
Lighting Designer: Richard Owen
Sound Designer: Peter Rice
Choreographer: Beverley Edmunds
Music Director: Richard Atkinson

fields.descriptive_line: Set model designed by Liz Ascroft for Jim Cartwright's play The Rise and Fall of Little Voice, Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester, 2002
fields.physical_description: Set model built on the speaker box of a gramophone - a leather covered box with metal grille on the front with three brown knobs to the lower right front. An octagonal wooden base has been attached to the record platter on top of the speaker box; half of the Manchester Royal Exchange Theatre's seating has been built up around the base, with green plastic seating, and seating all around the base. The stage set in the round is based on a record, with the label area central and different floor coverings emanating outwards to demark different rooms. Some areas have doors and windows recessed into the floor. There are several pieces of model furniture on the base including a bed, table and chairs, and a kitchen area. Centrally there is a painted model of an actress as LV. There is also a model lamp post, and a telegraph pole with wires that reach out to the third tier of seating. One of the wires has separated from the telegraph pole and is leaning down from the tiered seating. The arm of the gramophone is still attached to the speaker box, surrounding half of the stage area.

fields.public_access_description:
This is the set model for the 2004 production of The Rise and Fall of Little Voice at Manchester Royal Exchange Theatre. Set designer Liz Ascroft was inspired by the musical cues running through the play, combined with the fact that the Royal Exchange is a theatre in the round. Ascroft created a vinyl record-style stage setting with separate rooms marked out on the floor by different textiles and wall coverings; the stage revolved during the scene when the character of LV performed a medley of songs in the club, allowing everyone in the round to experience her voice. However, some critics suggested that the single-levelled set meant that parts of the story were difficult to stage, such as the character of Billy climbing the telegraph pole to speak to LV in her attic room. 

The set model’s base is an actual gramophone, with the set placed on the platter and the speaker box below. The arm of the gramophone is on the stage and bends along the edge of the round. This idea was not implemented in the final theatrical staging, presumably because the arm would block the view of those in the stalls.
